KED AND MISSISSIPPI RIVERS RAIL-ROAD.
Washington', D. C, November 30, 1850.
Sir:—Having been engaged by you, under the appropriation for the " survey
, ("eg from the valley of the Mississippi River to the Pacific Ocean." to ex-
'ne so much of the route as lies between the lower Mississippi, iu Louisiana,
1 d the Great Bend of Red River, in Arkansas, and having completed the work,
nave now the honor to report:
Earlv iu April I left Washington for the work, and on arriving at Louisville
wilh mv principal assistants, Messrs. J. K. Ford and S. Thayer Abert, proceeded
procure the equipment for the survey there. The floods of tiie Mississippi at
that time covering the whole bottom land, it became impracticable to commence
[besurvt-y at that extremity of the line, as originally intended ; and, with your
assent, I concluded to begin at the other end and work eastward. The party
was accordingly dispatched to Fuiion, by the way of the Red River, near which
point I joined them, having taken my route by the way of the Arkansas River
uudthe road from Little Rock to Washington, in Arkansas.
The party had been at work a week when J joined them, from which time I
continued iu direction of the work.
The country traversed between Ihe Red River and the Washita is hilly. Between the Washita aud tbe Mississippi level it may be described more particularly
thus: At Fulton the Red River is about eight hundred feet wide, with banks
about as high as the level of high water, and presenting no obstacle to bridging.
The course of the river is at first south, and afterwards east.
At about a quarter of a mile back from the margin of the river the ground rises
abruptly twenty-five feet to a table-land, which continues to the Bois d'Arc (or
Boclock) river, about eight miles, as we ran obliquely down the Red River
valley.
This stream runs southerly, and enters the Red River -about ten miles below
Fulton. Beyond tbe Bois d'Arc the country is billy, with frequent appearances
of rock. The Bodcom and Dorcheat are two other streams running southerly into
'he Red River; the first of which we cross at twenty, the last at forty miles from
fulton, as we ran ; and these are the last Upper Red River streams which we
meet.
